title: Have We Resigned Ourselves to Regular Mass Shootings?
sub_head: It wasn’t always this way, even when guns were widely available.
body:
Regarding your editorial “Young Men, Guns and Guardrails” (May 26): I am old enough to remember being able to buy guns by mail order. As Texas Gov. Greg Abbott pointed out, 18-year-olds have been able to buy long guns for over 60 years. Yet schools, churches, movie theaters and grocery stores were not getting shot up as they are today. I also remember saying the Pledge of Allegiance in school, going to church, obeying my teachers and respecting the police. There were no first-person-shooter videogames and there was a lot less violence in the media. My parents and grandparents expected respect, civility and courtesy.
The erosion of cultural norms together with the deinstitutionalization of those with drug problems and mental illness lays bare what happens when a society takes down the guardrails of civil behavior. We end up with more people driving into the ditch and taking innocents with them.
